metadata.title: Plain and Reinforced Concrete - Code of Practice

5.1.title: Cement
5.1.text: Cement used shall comply with the requirements of relevant Indian Standards.

5.2.title: Mineral Admixtures
5.2.text: Mineral admixtures such as fly ash, ground granulated blast-furnace slag shall conform to relevant standards.

5.4.title: Water
5.4.text: Water used for mixing and curing shall be clean and free from injurious amounts of oils, acids, alkalis, salts, sugar, organic materials.

5.6.title: Reinforcement
5.6.text: Steel reinforcement shall conform to the requirements of relevant Indian Standards.

6.1.title: Grades of Concrete
6.1.text: Concrete shall be designated by its characteristic compressive strength at 28 days.

6.2.title: Properties of Concrete
6.2.text: Characteristic strength, modulus of elasticity, and other properties shall be determined as per relevant standards.

6.2.2.title: Modulus of Elasticity
6.2.2.text: Modulus of elasticity Ec = 5000 * sqrt(fck) N/mm²

21.1.title: Cover to Reinforcement
21.1.text: Minimum cover shall be provided as per Table 16 and 16A depending on exposure conditions.
tables: Table 16A - Minimum Cover for Specified Exposure

23.1.title: Effective Span
23.1.text: The effective span of a member shall be calculated as specified in Clause 23.1.1 and 23.1.2.

23.1.1.title: Effective Span - Simply Supported
23.1.1.text: For simply supported beam or slab, effective span = clear span + effective depth OR c/c of supports, whichever is less.

23.1.2.title: Effective Span - Continuous
23.1.2.text: For continuous beam or slab, effective span = clear span between supports for interior spans.

23.2.1.title: Slenderness Limits - Beams
23.2.1.text: A simply supported or continuous beam shall be so proportioned that clear distance between lateral restraints does not exceed 60*b or 250*b²/d, whichever is less.

26.2.1.title: Development Length of Bars
26.2.1.text: Development length Ld = (φ * σs) / (4 * τbd), where τbd is design bond stress.

26.2.1.1.title: Design Bond Stress
26.2.1.1.text: Design bond stress τbd for deformed bars may be increased by 60% over values given in Table 21.

26.2.2.title: Anchoring Reinforcement
26.2.2.text: Anchorage of reinforcement shall be provided through development length, hooks, bends, or mechanical devices.

26.2.2.1.title: Minimum Bend Radius
26.2.2.1.text: Minimum internal radius of bend for bars shall be 2φ for bars ≤ 25mm and 3φ for bars > 25mm (deformed bars).

26.2.2.2.title: Stirrup Anchorage
26.2.2.2.text: Stirrups and ties shall be anchored with hooks. For seismic zones, 135° hooks with 6d ≥ 75mm extension required.

26.2.3.title: Standard Hooks and Bends
26.2.3.text: Standard hooks and bends shall conform to the requirements of IS 2502.

26.2.5.title: Lap Splices
26.2.5.text: Lap length for bars in tension/compression shall be calculated based on development length and location factors.
26.2.5.formula: Lap length = k * Ld (k = 1.0 to 2.0 based on location)

26.3.2.title: Minimum Spacing of Reinforcement
26.3.2.text: Horizontal distance between two parallel main bars shall not be less than max(bar diameter, aggregate size + 5mm, 20mm).

26.3.3.title: Maximum Spacing of Reinforcement
26.3.3.text: Maximum distance between parallel main bars shall not exceed 3*d or 300mm, whichever is smaller.

26.5.1.1.title: Minimum Shear Reinforcement
26.5.1.1.text: Minimum shear reinforcement shall be provided even when τv < τc. Asv_min = 0.4*b*sv / (0.87*fy).

26.5.1.2.title: Stirrup Spacing
26.5.1.2.text: Spacing of stirrups shall not exceed 0.75*d or 300mm, whichever is less, for vertical stirrups.

26.5.1.3.title: Side Face Reinforcement
26.5.1.3.text: Where depth of web in beam exceeds 750mm, side face reinforcement shall be provided along each face. Total area >= 0.1% of web area.

26.5.1.5.title: Stirrup Legs
26.5.1.5.text: For beams with width > 450mm, additional stirrup legs should be provided to ensure no compression bar is more than 150mm from a restrained bar.

26.5.1.6.title: Bent-up Bars
26.5.1.6.text: Bent-up bars should not carry more than half the shear force. Angle of bend typically 45° or 60°.

36.1.title: Limit State of Collapse - Flexure
36.1.text: Design for limit state of collapse in flexure shall be based on equilibrium and compatibility of strains.

36.4.2.title: Effective Width of Flange
36.4.2.text: Effective flange width bf = lo/6 + bw + 6*Df (T-beam) or lo/12 + bw + 3*Df (L-beam), not exceeding actual width.

38.1.title: Assumptions in Design
38.1.text: Design assumptions include: plane sections remain plane, maximum strain in concrete = 0.0035, stress-strain relationship as per IS 456, tensile strength of concrete ignored.

38.1.1.title: Neutral Axis Depth
38.1.1.text: Maximum depth of neutral axis xu_max = k*d, where k depends on grade of steel.

38.1.2.title: Stress Block Parameters
38.1.2.text: Rectangular stress block: depth = 0.42*xu, resultant compression = 0.36*fck*b*xu.

38.2.title: Singly Reinforced Sections
38.2.text: For singly reinforced sections, tension steel area Ast = Mu / (0.87*fy*(d - 0.42*xu)).

38.3.title: Doubly Reinforced Sections
38.3.text: When Mu > Mu_lim, compression reinforcement is required. Asc = (Mu - Mu_lim) / (fsc * (d - d')).

38.4.title: Flanged Beams
38.4.text: For T-beams and L-beams, if NA falls within flange (xu < Df), design as rectangular section with width bf.

40.1.title: Limit State of Collapse: Shear
40.1.text: Nominal shear stress τv = Vu / (b*d). Design shear strength τc depends on concrete grade and steel percentage.

40.2.title: Design Shear Strength of Concrete
40.2.text: Design shear strength τc is obtained from Table 19 based on percentage of tension steel and concrete grade.

40.3.title: Enhanced Shear Strength Near Supports
40.3.text: For sections within 2d from support face, enhanced shear strength = 2*d*τc/av may be used.

40.4.title: Shear Reinforcement Design
40.4.text: When τv > τc, shear reinforcement is required. Vus = (τv - τc) * b * d. Asv/sv = Vus / (0.87*fy*d).

40.5.1.title: Maximum Shear Stress
40.5.1.text: Maximum shear stress τc_max shall not exceed values in Table 20.

41.1.title: General - Design for Torsion
41.1.text: In structures where torsion is required for equilibrium, members shall be designed for torsion. Where torsion is due to compatibility, redistribution of loads may occur with cracking.

41.3.title: Critical Section for Torsion
41.3.text: Sections located at less than a distance d from face of support may be designed for torsion at distance d.

41.3.1.title: Equivalent Shear
41.3.1.text: Equivalent shear Ve = Vu + 1.6(Tu/b). This equivalent shear is used to check against maximum shear stress.

41.4.title: Reinforcement for Torsion
41.4.text: When τve exceeds τc, both transverse and longitudinal reinforcement shall be provided.

41.4.2.title: Longitudinal Reinforcement for Torsion
41.4.2.text: Longitudinal reinforcement shall be designed for equivalent moment Me = Mu + Mt, where Mt = Tu(1 + D/b)/1.7.

41.4.3.title: Transverse Reinforcement for Torsion
41.4.3.text: Closed stirrups required. Asv/sv = Tu/(b1*d1*0.87*fy) + Vus/(2.5*d1*0.87*fy). Spacing ≤ (x1+y1)/4 or 300mm.

43.1.title: Limit State of Serviceability: Deflection
43.1.text: Final deflection shall not normally exceed span/250. Deflection after construction of partitions shall not exceed span/350 or 20mm.

43.2.title: Control of Deflection - Span/Depth Ratios
43.2.text: For beams, span/depth ratio controls deflection. Basic ratios: cantilever=7, simply supported=20, continuous=26.

43.2.1.title: Modification Factors
43.2.1.text: Basic span/depth ratios are modified by factors for tension reinforcement (kt), compression reinforcement (kc), and flange (kf).

43.3.title: Crack Control
43.3.text: Surface crack width at service loads shall not exceed 0.3mm for normal exposure or 0.1mm for severe exposure.

43.4.title: Minimum Reinforcement
43.4.text: Minimum tension reinforcement shall be not less than As_min = 0.85*b*d/fy.

Annex G.title: Moments of Resistance of Beams and Slabs
Annex G.description: Coefficients for moment of resistance calculations

G-1.1.title: Doubly Reinforced Rectangular Sections
G-1.1.text: For doubly reinforced sections, the moment of resistance is Mu = Mu_lim + Mu2, where Mu2 = fsc × Asc × (d - d')

G-2.2.title: Flanged Beams - Neutral Axis in Web
G-2.2.text: For T-beams and L-beams with neutral axis in web, moment of resistance comprises flange contribution and web contribution.
